body:
Did some in person review:
- [x] Move pygments definitions to the cell styles that needs them.
- [x] See if we really need alltt and/or fancyvrb?
- [x] Create Jinja2 blocks for title, author, date and abstract
- [x] Use inch margins all around
- [x] Use same name for draw_prompt macro in different styles
- [x] Sphinx release/version should be removed
- [x] Strip down the Sphinx preprocessor

Cell styles that we want to support:
- Simple
- Notebook
  - If we can simplify by getting rid of the colored/bordered box, we might
    be able to get rid of the fancy mdframed stuff and its problems
- Python prompt version
  - B&W
  - Pygment colored
- IPython prompt version
  - B&W
  - Pygment colored
  - How to handle Out[] prompts?
Updated description, rebased, and ready to test/review.
The preview images look awesome! I hope to find some time in the near future to test this!
Thanks @jakobgager :smile:

From in person review with @ellisonbg :
- [x] Add abstract to base
- [x] s/Book/Report
- [x] Remove continuation prompts
- [x] Blue/red color scheme for IPython
- [x] Change default for all templates to IPython
Also post review, added a bibliography block.
I updated the screenshots in the description to match the altered output for the ipython & bw ipython styles

from 

```
nbconvert --to latex notebooks/Part\ 5\ -\ Rich\ Display\ System --post pdf
```

I get

```
[4 <./Part 5 - Rich Display System_files/Part 5 - Rich Display System_28_0.jpeg
>] [5]

! Package amsmath Error: \begin{aligned} allowed only in math mode.

See the amsmath package documentation for explanation.
Type  H <return>  for immediate help.
 ...                                              

l.632 \nabla
             \times \vec{\mathbf{B}} -\, \frac1c\, \frac{\partial\vec{\mathb...

? 
! Emergency stop.
```
in general, when creating a bunch of files of a given class, prefix seems better than suffix (style_ipython rather than ipython_style)

>  prefix seems better than suffix

Good tip, I've uploaded the changes

> ! Package amsmath Error: \begin{aligned} allowed only in math mode.

Sounds like the funky logic I wrote to fix the $$ tag spacing on math (https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/master/IPython/nbconvert/filters/latex.py#L66) is failing, could you paste a small portion of the tex around that line (632) please?

Funny issue. The first time I run pdflatex, latex complains about a missing language definition, and missing tikz.
However, when I run again this error disappears, even after deletion of all related files?

> even after deletion of all related files?

Really?  That is very very strange, haven't heard of anything like that so far.  The new pdf post processor logic (that @ellisonbg wrote, which was just merged into master a couple days ago and has been rebased into this PR) should clean ALL of the temporary files between runs for you.

It should also automatically run pdflatex 3 times...  I think it may abort if it encounters a critical failure, which may be a problem..  Maybe it should only abort on pdflatex failures after the final execution of pdflatex?

The following notebook converted fine with ipython 1.0.0 but results in an latex error using your branch:
http://nbviewer.ipython.org/c295019818fc09b669a4
Issue is due to In[4]
Thanks @jakobgager I'll take a look right now

Regarding the funny issue, it is quite tricky to reproduce the error. However I managed again (rename + switching from-and-to virtualenv) the error was 


IIRC there was something similar with older versions, so it might not related to this at all.
Will investigate further.
Btw. the I used the default calls for both issues `nbconvert --to latex foo.ipynb`

> l.23 \pgfsyspdfmark {pgfid1}{7815060}{36203544}

I used to get this error when I used the old simple cell style, left some of the temp files in the directory, and then tried to use the notebook cell style.  The problem was that the temporary files didn't have the dependencies necessary to run the more complex tex.  Still all the temporary files should be removed with the changes to the pdf post processor....  Not sure why you are seeing this
@jakobgager there was a missing escape_latex in the base, I just added it, please give a second whirl when you get a chance
It fixes the problem with your notebook on my machine.
Works also on my machine. I just wonder if the Output of In[4](print) should get some linebreaks?
It probably should, if it's not too complicated, #3959

I'm not quite sure why you have that macro block, what advantage does that give you over the existing blocks in null template? 

The output blocks are much more complex than the input blocks in that, they redirect to the display priority blocks.  If you have the output code in a separate file (included via include or import), that does not sit directly in the line of inheritance, you cannot perform this redirection since the display data logic belongs to the output template -  it's important that output templates are able to define the methods that describe how media gets written too the document, and for the styles to be able to respect and use that logic.

For example, if you want a two column template, you'll probably end up overriding the image outputs (among other things) to change the image sizes.  You may want to be able to use the IPython cell style with you template (or any of the other styles).  If the IPython style, and/or other styles, defines the method to write media to the page, then you could run into a large number of issues.

The coupling of cell style and output template is complicated by the fact that the output template does not just include the cell style, but the cell style must also be able to use blocks from the output template.

Additionally, some (actually every style except for the black and white templates) require custom Declarations and some of the styles require custom Packages.  If we were to try do it that way (I'm not saying that it would even work nicely) we would not only need a case for each style in the Input and Output macros, but also conditional logic in the Declarations and Package sections.

Right now there is an abstract and a base template, but I prefer to have separate.  There are 4 output templates, article, report, sphinx article, sphinx report and one template for each of the 6 cell styles.  We **could** minimize the file system clutter by merging some of the files together and still using the wonky conditional inheritance.  Personally, I prefer to keep the different logic for each style in different templates.  This may seem non-pythonic by ignoring the idea of one file being a module containing multiple classes, but I think that's okay in this case.

If you think I don't understand your idea, please provide a MWE (just a couple of files showing me what you envision as far as the inheritance structure is concerned).  Also, I've uploaded examples of how to do what you requested earlier in the nbconvert-examples repository (it's an open PR).

**Also** I'm not sure when I'll be home tonight, I'm going to visit my Dad, so maybe tomorrow we could Skype or Google hangout, it may be a more efficient way to communicate.  We could have others join in too.
I will look into a minimal implementation. I won't be around at any point today, but maybe tomorrow.

@minrk Here is why I don't think this method will work for us (because we need to be able to call back to a block in the document structure from within output blocks).

a.tplx

```
((*- for worksheet in nb.worksheets -*))
    ((*- for cell in worksheet.cells -*))
        ((*- block cell_contents scoped -*))

            cell method A

            ((*- block image scoped -*))
                image method A
            ((*- endblock image -*))

        ((*- endblock cell_contents -*))
    ((*- endfor -*))
((*- endfor -*))
```

b.tplx

```
((*- extends 'a.tplx' -*))

((* import 'c.tplx' as styles *))

((* block cell_contents *))
((( styles.output_area(cell) )))
((* endblock *))
```

c.tplx

```
((* macro output_area(cell) *))
((* block output_block *))

if has image:
((*- block image -*))
    ((( super() )))
((*- endblock image -*))

((* endblock *))
((* endmacro *))
```

d.tplx

```
((*- extends 'b.tplx' -*))

((*- block image -*))
    image method D
((*- endblock image -*))
```

Fails to compile with this message:
`UndefinedError: there is no parent block called 'image'.`
Which fails with or without d.tplx. I included d.tplx so the example matched my written description of the problem from Friday.

Ah, I should have included:

a.tplx is like our null and display_data templates
b.tplx is an output template
c.tplx is the proposed container of cell styles
d.tplx is like a custom user template
